document.title: Sewing a Handkerchief
document.introduction:
This tutorial shows you how to sew a handkerchief using a sewing machine. With just basic sewing supplies, this project takes about 30 minutes and is perfect for beginners. Note: This tutorial assumes you have basic knowledge of sewing-machine operation, including threading the machine and adjusting stitch settings.
The following materials are essential:
Sewing machine
One yard of cotton fabric
Thread (matching the fabric)
Sewing pins
Fabric scissors
Ruler or measuring tape
Fabric pencil or chalk
Pin cushion or small container (to safely hold pins)
Optional/Nice-to-Have: Iron or steamer (for pressing hems)

topic.introduction: To make the handkerchief, we will begin by cutting the fabric into a square. Accuracy at this stage ensures the finished handkerchief looks neat and professional. This step should take approximately 10 minutes.

steps.step: Lay your chosen cotton fabric on a clean, level surface so it can lie completely even.
Make sure the fabric is free of wrinkles or folds. If it is wrinkled, use a steamer or iron to smooth it out.
Take a ruler and align it along one edge of the fabric to measure accurately.
Using a fabric pencil or chalk, draw a straight vertical line 12 inches from the edge of the fabric.
Repeat on the adjacent edge to draw a horizontal line 12 inches from that edge, forming a square outline.
Double-check your measurements on all sides to ensure the square is even. Each side should be exactly 12 inches.
Pick up your fabric scissors and position your fingers on the surface beneath the fabric for stability.
Carefully cut along the outline of the square, trying to follow the lines as straight as possible.
Inspect the cut square to ensure the edges are even and straight.

topic.topicTitle: Create Additional Squares Using a Template
topic.introduction: If you want to make multiple handkerchiefs, the first square can serve as a template to ensure all pieces are identical. This process saves time and fabric.

steps.step: Once your square is perfectly cut, place it on the remaining fabric to use as a guide for cutting additional pieces.
Align the square so you maximize the use of the fabric and minimize waste.
If needed, secure the square in place with sewing pins to prevent it from shifting while you trace around it.
Using a fabric pencil or chalk, trace around the square onto the fabric.
Cut carefully along the traced lines to create another square that matches your original perfectly.
Repeat this process until you have cut all the squares you need from your fabric.

topic.introduction: Next, we will create a neat double-fold hem on each edge. Hems prevent fraying and give your handkerchief a professional finish. This should take about 5 to 10 minutes per square.

steps.step: Take one cut square of fabric and fold one edge up by ¼ inch.
Fold up the same edge by ¼ inch, creating a double-fold hem.
Hold the folded edge in place and secure it with sewing pins. Sewing pins are sharp. Handle with care to avoid injury.
Repeat steps 1 through 3 for all edges of the square.
Repeat the entire process for any remaining cut squares.

topic.introduction: Now, we will sew the folded hems to secure them. This step ensures your handkerchief is durable and neatly finished. Sewing each hem takes about 10 to 15 minutes per square.

steps.step: Ensure your sewing machine is plugged in and properly threaded. This guide assumes you know basic sewing-machine operations.
Set the machine for a straight stitch: Tension: ~4 Stitch length: ~2.5 Stitch width: 0
Take one pinned square and align the needle with the folded hem on one edge.

Slowly sew along the hem, removing pins as you go. Remember to backstitch at the beginning to secure the thread.
Sewing needles are sharp. Keep unused needles and pins in a pin cushion or secure container to avoid injury.
When you reach the end of the edge: Ensure the needle is in the fabric then lift the presser foot, rotate the fabric, and continue sewing the next edge.
After completing the hem on all sides, backstitch to secure the thread. Lift the presser foot and needle, then cut the thread.
Repeat this process for all remaining squares until all hems are stitched.

topic.introduction: Finally, we will complete the handkerchief by trimming threads and pressing the hems. This step ensures your handkerchief looks polished and professional.

steps.step: Trim any loose or extra threads from the hem.
Optional: Lightly press the hem with an iron to ensure it lies flat and looks neat.

Inspect all edges to make sure the stitching is secure and even.
Your handkerchief is now complete and ready for use!
